Title: HOLISTIC ASSESSMENT METHODOLOGY FOR POSITIVE ENERGY DISTRICTS
Abstract: Globally, cities are responsible for most of the world’s energy consumption and most of the carbon dioxide emissions. Therefore, the efficient transformation of urban energy systems is becoming a crucial step towards carbon neutrality and more effective climate protection. The Positive Energy District (PED) concept has been pointed out as one of the key principles of this path. The Positive Energy District concept leads towards an integrated and sustainable urban development with an emphasis on the use of renewable energy sources and attention shifting from energy performance at the level of individual buildings to the level of the entire district. However, PEDs represent a relatively new and still not sufficiently explored area in the field of sustainable development. The aim of this paper is to describe the technical part of the new holistic assessment and innovative process of stakeholder engagement to identify Positive Energy Districts in the early development phase that arises within the PED-ID project. The early development phase is crucial since the structure of the urban area is being decided along with its sustainability and climate protection levels. The assessment methodology is based on the creation and optimization of energy balance scenarios. Case studies of existing urban areas have been developed in order to verify the methodology. It is concluded that this innovative methodology devised for PED evaluation, together with strengthening of knowledge-based and decision-making framework, will help to accelerate the process of transforming the current urban energy systems into more efficient and renewable systems. © 2022 The Author(s).
Author Keywords: assessment methods; Positive energy districts; sustainable urban development
Summary: The aim of the PED-ID project is to accelerate the process of transforming the current urban energy systems into more efficient and renewable systems.

Authors: Calatan G.; Dico C.; Mircea C.G.R.; Toader T.
Author full names: Calatan, Gabriela (57188921972); Dico, Carmen (56006524100); Mircea, Călin G.R. (12794641800); Toader, Tudor (57218933256)
Title: THE INTEGRATION OF VERNACULAR CONSTRUCTION MATERIALS IN THE CONCEPT OF SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT
Source title: International Multidisciplinary Scientific GeoConference Surveying Geology and Mining Ecology Management, SGEM
Abstract: Lately, there is a growing need for humanity to get closer to nature and to a way of life so that the negative impact on it to be as small as possible. One cannot talk about durable development without taking into account the sustainability criterion which is essential in all areas of activity. Traditional constructions made of masonry elements from unburned clay or other vernacular materials, using sheep wool mattresses for thermal insulation, successfully meet the conditions imposed by this criterion. Constructions made of natural materials, ensure the responsible use of non-renewable natural resources, the possibility of reuse and recycling of materials, contribute to environmental protection and pollution reduction, are energy saving and provide an hygienic, pleasant and healthy living climate. The aim of this paper is to present the experimental results obtained regarding the mechanical properties of the elements of unburned clay masonry with the addition of vegetable fibers from waste and of bio-eco-innovative wool mattresses, of different thicknesses. Following the results obtained on the 2 types of construction materials, based on clay with the addition of vegetable fibers, and sheep wool mattresses as thermal insulation material, it can be stated that they can be used successfully in construction. © 2022 International Multidisciplinary Scientific Geoconference. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: bio-eco-innovative thermal insulation mattresses; healthy environment; unfired clay elements; vapor permeability; vegetable fibers
Index Keywords: Energy conservation; Environmental protection; Masonry materials; Mineral wool; Sustainable development; Thermal insulation; Wool; Yarn; Area of activities; Bio-eco-innovative thermal insulation mattress; Healthy environments; Masonry elements; Sheep wool; Sustainability criteria; Traditional constructions; Unfired clay element; Vapor permeability; Vegetable fiber; Vegetables
Summary: Traditional constructions made of masonry elements from unburned clay or other vernacular materials, using sheep wool mattresses for thermal insulation, successfully meet the conditions imposed by this criterion.

Title: Potential Improvement of Eggshell powder in the Mechanical and Durability properties with GGBS and Flyash based Geopolymer concrete
Source title: 4th International Conference on Emerging Research in Electronics, Computer Science and Technology, ICERECT 2022
Abstract: This Research looked closely at the Acid attack, Carbonation, Water absorption and Sorptivity test distinctiveness of geopolymerconcrete made from Flyash, Eggshell powder, and GGBS. One of the efforts made to promote sustainable construction is the use of Geopolymer concrete. It emits less greenhouse gas than conventional concrete. Additionally investigated and the outcomes with control concrete were the impact of accelerated corrosion on Geopolymer concrete. Through the investigation, it was discovered that geopolymer concrete is less porous and has a smaller linear curve than control concrete. Since concrete has been used for construction, it has been exposed to the effects of acidic environments. Therefore, when concrete is used in an environment where it will be exposed to the effects of acids, it is exposed to these effects for the duration of its usage. Now, the use of acids which used for checking the durability characteristics of Geo-polymer concrete to conduct the test with 5% H2SO4 solution and 5% H2CO3 solution to the concrete specimens to find out the acid attack test and carbonation test. However, the sorptivity and absorption test is going to be conducted for the concrete specimens in water by taking the samples before and after the absorption of water. Now, all the test results values are to be taken on 28,56,84 days with the involvement of acids in concrete and other cases without the involvement of acids in it. © 2022 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Eggshell powder; Flyash; GGBS; H2CO3 solution; H2SO4; RGL Liquid
Index Keywords: Carbonation; Concretes; Corrosion; Durability; Fly ash; Geopolymers; Greenhouse gases; Inorganic polymers; Sustainable development; Acid attack; Concrete specimens; Eggshell powder; Exposed to; Flyash; Geopolymer concrete; GGBS; H2CO3 solution; RGL liquid; Sorptivity; Water absorption
Summary: The purpose of this research was to investigate the durability characteristics of Geopolymer concrete made from Flyash, Eggshell powder, and GGBS.

Author full names: Godfrey, Ian (57211297476); Brenes, José Pablo Sibaja (58160929000)
Title: Practical Applications for UAS Designed to Assist Climatologists in Studying Toxic Gas Emissions Relative to Climate Change
Source title: Springer Proceedings in Mathematics and Statistics
Abstract: The rapid advancement of the Unmanned Aerial Systems (UAS) technology and applications provide a unique opportunity to assist the United Nations with their 17 Sustainable Development Goals (SDG’s). Further enhancement of the UAS sector has brought forward tangible applications that illustrate how this technology can assist in improving community health, collective education and stimulate economic growth. There are numerous practical examples of how UAS contribute to the SDG’s of climatologists today. Outlined in this paper are some of the most prominent UAS applications and their resulting benefits to society. The development and global roll out of the UAS has created significant opportunity for climate scientists studying toxic gas emissions and the chemistry of Earth’s atmosphere. UAS make emission monitoring more accurate, contribute to gas leak detection at industrial facilities and greatly assist plant efficiency and optimization. UAS help simplify the data collection process by allowing remote pilots to quickly survey industrial plants and allow them to carry payloads of scientific equipment such as spectrometers which can be used for Differential Optical Absorbance Spectroscopy (DOAS) or thermal cameras designed to detect thermal anomalies. The research illustrated here shows real-world practical examples of using UAS technology on natural emissions at the active crater of the Poás Volcano in Costa Rica and the Industrial power plant of Tampa Electric (TECO) in Tampa, Florida. © 2023, The Author(s), under exclusive license to Springer Nature Switzerland AG.
Author Keywords: Acid rain; Atmospheric chemistry; Climate change; Ecosystems; Energy; Forests; Natural resources; Oceans; Pollution; Preservation; Sustainability; Sustainable Development Goals SDG’s; Technology; Transportation; Urbanization; Water
Index Keywords: Acid rain; Antennas; Climate change; Deforestation; Economics; Gas emissions; Gas plants; Industrial emissions; Industrial research; Spectrometers; Sustainable development; Unmanned aerial vehicles (UAV); Energy; Forest; Ocean; Preservation; Sustainable development goal sustainable development goal; Technologies and applications; Technology; Toxic gas emissions; Unmanned aerial systems; Urbanization; Atmospheric chemistry
Summary: The Unmanned Aerial Systems (UAS) sector has brought forward tangible applications that illustrate how this technology can assist in improving community health, collective education and stimulate economic growth.

Title: GREEN COMPETITIVENESS IN WASTE MANAGEMENT IN URBAN SOCIETY
Source title: International Multidisciplinary Scientific GeoConference Surveying Geology and Mining Ecology Management, SGEM
Abstract: Climate change and environmental degradation pose an existential threat to the EU and the world. The aim of the Green Agreement for Europe is to make Europe climate neutral by 2050, to support the economy through green technologies, to create a sustainable industry and transport and to reduce pollution. Turning climate and environmental challenges into opportunities will make the transformation fair and inclusive. The European Commission is helping EU Member States to design and implement reforms that support ecological transformation and contribute to achieving the goals of the Green Agreement for Europe. It also helps to design the necessary procedures in central and local administrations and to set up the coordination structures necessary to implement environmental policies. The aim of this article was to propose possible strategies for the use and support of the competitiveness of companies in the Czech Republic in meeting the objectives of the European Union. In the interests of competitiveness, this contribution leads to the strengthening of the SME sector, the reduction of market barriers, the facilitation of foreign investment and trade, the development of research and innovation, better management of public-private partnerships and the optimization of state-owned enterprises. © 2022 International Multidisciplinary Scientific Geoconference. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: green competitives; policy; strategy; waste management
Index Keywords: Climate change; Commerce; Competition; Environmental protection; Investments; Climate challenges; Design and implements; Ecological transformation; Environmental challenges; European Commission; Green competitive; Green technology; Strategy; Sustainable industries; Sustainable transport; Waste management
Summary: The aim of this article was to propose possible strategies for the use and support of the competitiveness of companies in the Czech Republic in meeting the objectives of the European Union.

Authors: Claudia D.C.A.; Teodor M.-S.; Casiana M.; Iaroslav L.K.; Nicoleta M.-S.
Author full names: Claudia, Duma Copcea Anișoara (57207858885); Teodor, Mateoc-Sîrb (55928052200); Casiana, Mihut (58260256500); Iaroslav, Lațo Karel (58158131800); Nicoleta, Mateoc-Sîrb (58157778600)
Title: THE PEDOLOGICAL STUDY OF LANDS IN DUBOVA, MEHEDINŢI COUNTY, ROMANIA
Source title: International Multidisciplinary Scientific GeoConference Surveying Geology and Mining Ecology Management, SGEM
Abstract: The objective of this paper is the morphological characterization as well as the establishment of soil quality classes in the commune of Dubova, Mehedinti County, Romania. Soil is a primary component for plant production, although it is often considered only as a physical support for plant growth. However, the concerns of mankind over the sustainability of agriculture have made it possible to consider that soil is a living, high-quality system and should, therefore, be preserved. This is the result of several interactions between biological components, including microbial communities, essential for physical-chemical operation. Agricultural crops are threatened by diseases transmitted through the soil, making them difficult to control because of the “hidden” character of pathogens and low efficiency of conventional treatments. These practices greatly affect the quality of the soil, which, in turn, affects the state of crop quality. One of the goals of this paper is to show that, despite the age of the concept of soil quality and the existence of numerous studies, the application of soil quality recommendations would play an important role in crops. However, there is a certain methodology for obtaining soil quality indices that could be suggested in this paper, a methodology based and developed on the basis of previously conducted research in the field. Under current conditions, highlighted by an intensification of globalization processes, sustainable development brings together the main economic and social factors to meet the present needs of mankind without compromising those of future generations. © 2022 International Multidisciplinary Scientific Geoconference. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: soil; soil quality; soil resources; soil sustainability
Index Keywords: Crops; Disease control; Sustainable development; Biological components; High quality; Morphological characterization; Plant growth; Plant production; Quality systems; Romania; Soil resources; Soil sustainability; Soils qualities; Soils
Summary: The aim of this paper is to show that, despite the age of the concept of soil quality, the application of soil quality recommendations would play an important role in crops. Authors: Blate M.; Abu-Orf M.; Dursun D.; Landy K.; Murray C.; Kaiser N.; Sharp R.
Author full names: Blate, Micah (57205617821); Abu-Orf, Mohammad (6603381108); Dursun, Derya (13607140200); Landy, Kelly (58168703100); Murray, Conner (57202153564); Kaiser, Nicole (58168703200); Sharp, Robert (7201356658)
Title: WRF Project# 5307: Evaluation of Source Separated Organic Feedstock Pretreatment and Management Practices
Source title: 95th Water Environment Federation Technical Exhibition and Conference, WEFTEC 2022
Abstract: Source Separated Organics (SSO) co-digestion with wastewater solids at Water Resource Recovery Facilities (WRRFs) offers promise to advance sustainability through beneficial reuse of the organic fraction of pre- and post-consumer waste streams (source separated organics), which would otherwise be disposed in landfills. Promoting SSO diversion from landfills to anaerobic digestion (AD) is predicated on SSO feedstock pretreatment to enhance the digestibility and conveyance of SSOs. A comprehensive evaluation of SSO pretreatment technologies was provided in this study to demonstrate the compatibility and effectiveness of numerous pretreatment technologies as implemented in case studies worldwide. This project, as funded by the Water Research Foundation, aims to comprehensively evaluate SSO pretreatment technologies with guidance from existing facilities to develop recommendations for SSO pretreatment alternatives for utilities considering SSO diversion. Copyright © 2022 Water Environment Federation.
Author Keywords: CASE STUDIES; CO-DIGESTION IMPACTS; PRETREATMENT; SOURCE SEPARATED ORGANICS
Index Keywords: Feedstocks; Land fill; Source separation; Sustainable development; Water conservation; Water resources; Case-studies; CO-DIGESTION IMPACTS; Codigestion; Feedstock management; Feedstock pretreatment; Organic feedstocks; Organics diversion; Pre-treatments; Pretreatment technology; Source separated organics; Anaerobic digestion
Summary: The aim of this study is to evaluate Source Separated Organics technologies with guidance from existing facilities to develop recommendations for SSO alternatives for utilities considering SSO diversion.

Title: CHALLENGES AND PROBLEMS FOR THE ECONOMY AND ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGEMENT
Source title: International Multidisciplinary Scientific GeoConference Surveying Geology and Mining Ecology Management, SGEM
Abstract: Theoretically, environmental management is still seen as a relatively young field that is rapidly evolving in search of ways to deal with natural threats and problems caused by human activities and related to the search for opportunities to provide and implement Sustainable Development. Environmental problems are intertwined with socioeconomic problems, especially in poor developing countries. In addition, environmental management faces a number of challenges in the modern world. Increasingly, countries will face a number of challenges, which will be a major threat to developing countries, as they do not have sufficient financial and material resources and, on the other hand, have similar socio-economic and physical problems. This article will attempt to outline the socio-economic problems resulting from rising average temperatures, which will outline the challenges facing institutions responsible for environmental management processes. Attention will be paid to the emergence of unstable and sometimes extreme weather conditions, including the increase in the intensity of solar radiation, the increase in water supply problems. In addition, the challenges of environmental management and environmental assessment of soils are linked to the ever-increasing share of contaminated and nutrient-poor soils for plants. Also noteworthy is the implementation of reduced control by the responsible institutions for vectors of diseases on flora and fauna. The lack of regular funding to monitor indicators to assess progress and success in developing and solving environmental and social problems should not be overlooked. Through the use and conduct of comprehensive statistical analysis, descriptive analysis, diagnostic and forecasting analysis, an attempt will be made to identify the main problems facing the economy and environmental management, as well as to outline the challenges facing developing countries in the 21st century. © 2022 International Multidisciplinary Scientific Geoconference. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: administrative units; environmental economy; environmental management; government policy; regional development; regional economy
Index Keywords: Developing countries; Diagnosis; Disease control; Economics; Facings; Regional planning; Sustainable development; Water supply; Administrative unit; Economy and environmental; Environmental economy; Environmental problems; Human activities; Management IS; Natural threats; Regional development; Regional economy; Socio-economic problems; Environmental management
Summary: This article will attempt to outline the socio-economic problems resulting from rising average temperatures, which will outline the challenges facing institutions responsible for environmental management processes.

Authors: Knight M.; Brisolara K.; Maal-Bared R.; Steeves H.; Schmidt J.
Author full names: Knight, Mark (57205989854); Brisolara, Kari (37096680800); Maal-Bared, Rasha (12762191200); Steeves, Helena (57198864080); Schmidt, Jordan (57211783507)
Title: Beyond COVID: The Value of Wastewater Based Epidemiology (WBE) Monitoring for Municipal and Industrial Systems
Source title: 95th Water Environment Federation Technical Exhibition and Conference, WEFTEC 2022
Abstract: The goal of this paper is to demonstrate how Wastewater Based Epidemiology (WBE) can be used after COVID-19 in both Municipal and Industrial wastewater systems to proactively monitor, manage, and avoid risks that could negatively impact the business continuity and resiliency of an organization. The history of WBE will first be reviewed to show how it has been used to maximize public health protection and social well-being while minimizing economic impacts and unintended consequences in public and private settings. The design of a WBE monitoring program for Closed, Semi-Closed, and Open Municipal and Industrial wastewater systems will be evaluated through a couple of case studies. Alignment between WBE programs and an organizations’ risk management programs, sustainability goals, and ethical considerations will also be explored. Copyright © 2022 Water Environment Federation.
Author Keywords: Ethics; Industrial Wastewater Monitoring; Municipal Wastewater Monitoring; Public Health Protection; Risk Management; Sustainability; Wastewater Based Epidemiology (WBE)
Index Keywords: Epidemiology; Health risks; Philosophical aspects; Public health; Sustainable development; Industrial systems; Industrial wastewater monitoring; Industrial wastewaters; Municipal system; Municipal wastewater monitoring; Municipal wastewaters; Public health protection; Risks management; Waste water systems; Wastewater based epidemiology; Risk management
Summary: The impacts of CO-19 on human health and the environment have been well-documented.

Authors: Maitieg M.; Rachmat F.; Baseef H.; Al Hadyani F.
Author full names: Maitieg, Mohamed (58151696400); Rachmat, Febry (58151382400); Baseef, Hussam (58151696500); Al Hadyani, Fahad (37070353700)
Title: Operations Sustainability During COVID-19 Pandemic
Abstract: The paper aims to describe the experiences, challenges faced, and lessons learnt on how The Company Well Services division is managing the risks associate to COVID-19. The global COVID-19 pandemic spread in late 2019 and turned into one of the biggest challenges facing all industries including the oil and gas industry- in decades. The most challenging aspect of COVID-19 is its contagion rate, and its ability to spread from both non-symptomatic and symptomatic people to others who are in close contact through respiratory droplets, by direct contact with infected persons, or by contact with contaminated objects and surfaces. Today, we must consider this new reality into business continuity planning and take all necessary precautions to mitigate its spread within the organization. As the health and safety of the employees and contractors is paramount to the Company and based on the Company commitment to provide better service quality to its clients, a thorough emergency response system that includes precaution measures to help fighting against COVID-19 and its potential to negatively impact the business was created. Furthermore, The Company COVID-19 Management Standard set the minimum requirements, to manage the risks associate to the COVID-19. A Crisis Management Team was formed to oversee the implementation of COVID-19 decisions and raise awareness within the Company. All field personnel were required to comply to COVID-19 precautions during operations. With the implementation of new procedures, we were able to maintain the lowest confirmed case numbers among all the companies in our operational sector. Though it was challenging at the beginning for employees to comply, the new requirements have become the normal standard today. These new measures focus on the importance of employee health and safety when working through COVID-19 pandemic and has helped to educate people on the importance of following health and safety procedures as way of life for everyone while maintaining the Company Operational Sustainability. Copyright © 2022, International Petroleum Technology Conference.
Index Keywords: Emergency services; Gas industry; Gasoline; Human resource management; Sustainable development; Business continuity planning; Direct contact; Emergency response systems; Health and safety; Lesson learnt; Management standards; Minimum requirements; Oil and Gas Industry; Service Quality; Take-all; COVID-19
Summary: The Company Well Services division of Schlumberger has published a paper on how it managed the risks associated with the CO-19 pandemic.
